stem: The nurse is performing a neurological assessment. Match each cranial nerve (CN) with its correct clinical test or function.

columns.text: Checking pupil constriction and extraocular movement.
Asking the client to smile, frown, and show teeth.
Testing hearing via the whisper test or Rinne/Weber tests.
Asking the client to stick out their tongue and move it side-to-side.

rationale.correct: Cranial nerve assessment localizes brainstem function. (r1) CN II is for sight. (r2) CN III controls most eye movements and pupillary light reflex. (r3) CN VII controls the muscles of facial expression. (r4) CN VIII is for hearing and balance. (r5) CN XII controls tongue movement.
rationale.incorrect: CN V (Trigeminal - not shown) is for facial sensation and chewing, often confused with CN VII.
clinicalPearls: Assessment of CN IX (Glossopharyngeal) and CN X (Vagus) is critical for patients at risk for aspiration (swallowing and gag reflex).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember: CN V is for 'Feeling' and 'Feeding' (Sensation/Chewing). CN VII is for 'Face' (Expression).

reviewUnits.heading: Cranial Nerve Assessment
reviewUnits.body: Nurses perform focused cranial nerve exams for patients with stroke, head trauma, or increased ICP. Changes in CN function are early indicators of neurological decline.
